sections.name: Situational Judgement
sections.description: Situational Judgement involves understanding real-world situations and identifying critical factors and appropriate behaviour in dealing with them

stems.text: Eloise is a junior doctor who has been working at a practice for a number of years. Today, she heard news that one of her patients passed away today, and she feels devastated – even though she keeps trying to tell herself that it wasn’t her fault. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Eloise when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: Eloise is likely to experience a number of deaths over her career as a doctor
questions.explanation: While this may be true, it is never easy to deal with the death of a patient and this fact won’t help Eloise’s mental state

questions.text: That the patient had a terminal illness and was bound to pass away
questions.explanation: This fact will not help Eloise and is not the focus of the scenario, her need to express and deal with her grief over her patient's passing is the crux here

questions.text: That Eloise is aware that it wasn’t her fault that the patient passed away
questions.explanation: Eloise’s self-awareness is very important in this situation, and, after giving it some time, it may help her come to terms with the situation

questions.text: That Eloise has a strong support network
questions.explanation: It is very important that Eloise relies upon her support network to help her through this tough time and negotiate her overwhelming emotions

questions.text: That the hospital has a counselling service for staff
questions.explanation: While not an immediate concern, this counselling service may be useful for Eloise in the future – if she feels the need for it

stems.text: Two medical students, Rachel and Sherry, enter a consulting room and see a patient lying on the bed, unconscious. The doctor said that this patient has recently had a stroke. The students read the notes with regards to his social history, the patient is a regular smoker and drinker. The patient also appears to be overweight. Once they leave the room, Sherry states that with his lifestyle and his state, the patient is a ticking time bomb. She then says that people should take better care of themselves. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Rachel in this situation?

questions.text: Say nothing
questions.explanation: While not awful as remaining silent will show that Rachel does not agree with Sherry nor want to discuss the matter further, it would be appropriate to express her disagreement

questions.text: Politely express that Sherry’s comments are unfair
questions.explanation: It is important for doctors and medical students to be empathetic and understanding – not judgemental. It is thus appropriate for Rachel to politely point this out in a non-confrontational manner

questions.text: Report Sherry’s comment to the supervisor
questions.explanation: This is a disproportionate response to the issue at hand, it should be resolved at a local level first and raised with Sherry instead

questions.text: Inform Sherry about how there may be other factors, including genetic and socioeconomic, that we aren’t aware of
questions.explanation: This is a polite way to alert Sherry to the importance of empathy and consideration for patients

questions.text: Express her agreement to avoid conflict
questions.explanation: This is highly inappropriate as it will only serve to reinforce Sherry’s judgemental views of the patient

stems.text: Jerry is a senior doctor working at a GP clinic. He is seeing an elderly patient, Theo, for a sore throat. Jerry believes that this is just a cold and a number of further tests rules out the potential of anything more serious. Jerry tells Theo this and says that he should get some rest over the next few days. Theo insists that he gets some medication or antibiotics. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Jerry in this situation?

questions.text: Give Theo additional medication
questions.explanation: Jerry should not allow himself to be bullied by the patient and should administer medication only for appropriate reasons

questions.text: Examine Theo once more to determine whether this may be helpful
questions.explanation: One examination should suffice, and Jerry’s time is a consideration; however, doing so will display Jerry’s consideration of Theo’s concerns and may help allay them

questions.text: Tell Theo not to pester him for medication
questions.explanation: This is a very rude and inflammatory thing to say and will only escalate the situation

questions.text: Reiterate what he has just said about the fact that Theo’s sore throat is likely to be a cold
questions.explanation: Repeating himself and telling Theo what he already knows is not going to address the situation and make him more cooperative

questions.text: Give Theo a placebo
questions.explanation: It is not at all appropriate to give a patient a placebo in this situation and doing so will be dishonest and deceptive

stems.text: Sophia is working as a medical student at a hospital. Her supervisor is very strict and has set a number of tasks to be done in a very short period of time. Sophia feels that a lot of the tasks are not relevant to her clinical skills and believes they aren’t explained properly. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Sophia in this situation?

questions.text: Seek advice from her academic mentor responsible for this placement
questions.explanation: Any concerns should be passed on to the relevant member of staff responsible for the unit

questions.text: Politely ask the supervisor for more times and more thorough explanations
questions.explanation: While this may help alleviate the strain placed on Sophia, the supervisor may be rushed for time and not be able to facilitate Sophia’s requests

questions.text: Work harder to impress the supervisor
questions.explanation: While not terrible, if Sophia has concerns and wishes to complete more clinically related tasks, she should express her concerns

questions.text: Complain about her supervisor
questions.explanation: Sophia should seek to resolve the issue locally first and perhaps vocalise her concerns with the supervisor before escalating

questions.text: Not complete the tasks
questions.explanation: Sophia shouldn’t simply cease completing the tasks assigned to her, she should communicate her concerns and resolve the issue

stems.text: Brayden is a dental student at a clinic. He notices the dentist, Dr Lee, bring out an anaesthetic that he will inject into the patient. After reviewing the patient notes, Brayden notices that she is allergic to that anaesthetic. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Brayden in this situation?

questions.text: Discuss this with Dr Lee as soon as possible
questions.explanation: The situation should be resolved immediately to prevent the patient being administered that anaesthetic

questions.text: Let Dr Lee know after the procedure
questions.explanation: Brayden should not delay the communication of this information – as it may result in the patient taking the anaesthetic that they are allergic to

questions.text: Swap the anaesthetic for one that the patient is not allergic to
questions.explanation: It is very inappropriate to change the prescription without the proper (Dr Lee’s) authority

questions.text: Ask the patient if they are allergic to anything
questions.explanation: While it is important to confirm whether the patient is allergic to this anaesthetic, the matter should be raised with Dr Lee first

questions.text: Take no action as there must have been a mistake in the notes
questions.explanation: Action must be taken to avoid the administration of an anaesthetic that may cause an allergic reaction, Brayden cannot assume an error in the notes has been made

stems.text: Raj is a GP. As he enters the reception area, intending to collect the next patient, he is approached by a different patient, Margaret. Margaret insists she had an appointment and has been waiting for a long time. Raj checks his booking schedule and does not see Margaret’s appointment next, or for the rest of the day for that matter. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Raj in this situation?

questions.text: Ask the receptionist if they know what’s happened
questions.explanation: It is appropriate to gather more information so that Raj can then work on resolving the situation

questions.text: Quickly squeeze Margaret in before seeing the next patient
questions.explanation: Raj should treat each patient with the attention, and for a sufficient time, and should not rush as this may compromise patient care

questions.text: Apologise to Margaret for her wait
questions.explanation: It is both suitable and professional for Raj to apologise for Margaret’s wait

questions.text: After the situation is resolved, look into what error has been made and try to rectify it so this does not occur in the future
questions.explanation: It is very important for doctors and health systems as a whole to review any errors and ensure that these mistakes do not repeat

questions.text: Tell Margaret that she hasn’t booked in and he can’t see her today
questions.explanation: This is inappropriate on two fronts – Raj shouldn’t impart blame on Margaret (as the clinic might have made a booking error) and, secondly, he should try to resolve the situation such that Margaret can be seen (by Raj, if he has a gap, or another doctor)

stems.text: You are a medical student at a clinical placement in a medical hospital. You notice a young boy walking by himself in one of the wards, with no parents nearby. You have a patient consultation to attend in 5 minutes.  How appropriate are each of the following responses for you to take in this scenario?

questions.text: Ignore the boy as you have a consultation to attend to and it is not your duty to help out
questions.explanation: This is very inappropriate as it is unreasonable to assume that somebody else will resolve the situation and the welfare of the boy should be the main priority

questions.text: Ask a passing nurse to tend to the boy
questions.explanation: While this is better than doing nothing, the nurse might be busy and there is no guarantee that s/he will tend to the boy

questions.text: Approach the boy and ask him where his parents are
questions.explanation: It is essential that you gather more information about the boy’s situation and determine where his parents are in order to decide how to progress further

questions.text: Lead the boy to the children’s play area and then attend the consultation
questions.explanation: While this may not sound bad on the surface, all you will be doing is moving the boy to another location (away from where the parents perhaps left him)

questions.text: Inform your supervisor that you may be a bit late to the consultation and tend to the boy/help him find his parents
questions.explanation: This is the most appropriate course of action – as it is professional to inform others when you have been delayed and resolving the issue with the boy is the major priority

stems.text: You are the captain of your school’s soccer team. 2 team members have been arguing and now refuse to talk to each other. How appropriate are each of the following responses for you to take in this scenario?

questions.text: Do not take action and let them resolve the situation
questions.explanation: As the team captain, you should try to take action to rectify the situation and, as they are not talking, it is highly unlikely they will be able to do resolve it themselves

questions.text: Apologise to the teammates on behalf of the other
questions.explanation: This is only a temporary fix to the issue and the team members should resolve the issue (and apologise) to one another – not via a third party

questions.text: Complain to the coach
questions.explanation: While not awful, it is best to resolve such disputes locally first – rather than escalating the situation

questions.text: Ask both team members, privately, for their perspective on the dispute
questions.explanation: It is definitely appropriate for the captain here to attempt to investigate the situation further so that he can determine how to progress

questions.text: Ask the coach for advice
questions.explanation: It is appropriate to approach others for advice; however, the captain should first attempt to resolve the situation himself before doing so

stems.text: You have received a poor mark in your first assignment as a 3rd year medical student. You believe that you did not deserve that mark and your assessor has marked you unfairly. How appropriate are each of the following responses for you to take in this scenario?

questions.text: Complain to your academic tutor
questions.explanation: While this may help resolve the issue if you believe unfair marking has taken pace, it is important to review the assessor’s feedback and take some time to process the feedback without immediately making a complaint

questions.text: Ask other students what they were scored by this assessor
questions.explanation: This may help determine whether this assessor is a strict marker, however other students do not have an obligation to divulge their marks and other students’ marks won’t provide a definite indication of unfair marking

questions.text: Review the assessor’s feedback, reflect on your work and then choose how to proceed
questions.explanation: It is extremely important to objectively reflect on your marks and determine how to improve rather than simply raise a complaint

questions.text: Understand that the feedback/grades will balance out over time
questions.explanation: While this may help you rationalise the situation, it is not reasonable to assume that this will naturally happen – the situation must be addressed actively

questions.text: Approach the assessor directly to complain about their marking
questions.explanation: You should first seek to determine if there is any truth to the marking and take some time to process the feedback without immediately making a complaint. Directly confronting the assessor is also not advisable whatsoever

stems.text: You are a medical student at a clinical placement in a medical hospital. You notice a young boy walking by himself in one of the wards, with no parents nearby. The boy looks upset. How appropriate are each of the following responses for you to take in this scenario?

questions.text: Do not take any action
questions.explanation: If the boy is lost, as it seems, you must take action immediately for the welfare of the boy and not assume others will take action instead

questions.text: Ask the boy to return to the waiting area
questions.explanation: While the boy may have wandered off from his parents in the waiting area, you do not know for sure whether this is the case – you may simply be leading him away from his parents

questions.text: Ask the boy if he knows where his parents are
questions.explanation: It is extremely important to determine whether the boy is, in fact, lost and use this information to determine how to proceed with this

questions.text: Approach the boy and try to comfort/reassure him
questions.explanation: The boy is evidently upset and, hence, it would definitely be appropriate to try to first comfort him

questions.text: Get advice from your supervisor
questions.explanation: While it is appropriate to seek advice from a supervisor when you are unsure, the situation is urgent and by the time you consult your supervisor the boy might have walked off – so this isn’t the most feasible course of action

stems.text: Your friend has both wanted to study art since the beginning of high school. Although she still wants to study art, her parents are adamant that she should study medicine. How appropriate are each of the following responses for you to take in this scenario?

questions.text: Tell her to go against what her parents have said and follow her dreams
questions.explanation: While she should be encouraged to follow her passion, rather than choose a course purely based on parental advice, doing so in the manner suggested by this response is likely to be controversial and, potentially, spark disharmony in their household

questions.text: Encourage her to vocalise her passion to study art to her parents
questions.explanation: It is important for your friend to communicate their aspirations to their parents rather than remain quiet and feed into the misconception that she will study medicine

questions.text: Encourage her to study medicine due to the ability to help others
questions.explanation: While this is a valid point and it is ok to express the benefits of study medicine to your friend, she has already expressed her passion to study art

questions.text: Talk to your friend’s parents directly and tell them about her aspirations
questions.explanation: It would be very inappropriate for you personally to approach the parents and, instead, she should be encouraged to discuss with her parents

questions.text: Be understanding and empathetic to your friend’s difficult situation
questions.explanation: As a friend, you should be there to support her and provide reassurance

stems.text: Your friend wishes to study medicine but is not sure which path to follow to do so. She has been offered a position in biomedicine, with guaranteed entry into postgraduate medicine. She also has the option to study undergraduate medicine at an interstate university. How appropriate are each of the following responses for you to take in this scenario?

questions.text: Encourage your friend to study undergraduate medicine as it is a shorter course
questions.explanation: The length of the course alone should not be a reason to consider undergraduate medicine – you should check in with your friend before making such a recommendation

questions.text: Encourage your friend to do additional research into the entry pathways to determine which is a better fit for her situation
questions.explanation: Before making any decision regarding a career path, conducting extra research is definitely advisable

questions.text: Encourage her to discuss these options with a qualified career’s counsellor
questions.explanation: A career counsellor will likely provide your friend with extra information and assist her in the decision-making process

questions.text: Encourage her to study postgraduate medicine as you heard, from a family friend, that students who graduate via this pathway tend to be more mature by the time they become a doctor
questions.explanation: While this may be true, anecdotal evidence alone should not be used to dictate your friend’s path

questions.text: Tell your friend that it is completely up to her
questions.explanation: While this is true in essence, such a remark is not helpful whatsoever and, instead, a more proactive response (such as encouraging her to consult a career’s counsellor) would be far more appropriate

stems.text: You are a first-year medical student working on a group task with 5 other classmates. This task contributes 30% to your coursework grade and is, hence, a major assignment. The deadline is fast approaching, and a number of group members haven’t finished their sections yet. For every day late the assignment is submitted, 10 % of the available marks are deducted.How appropriate are each of the following responses for you to take in this scenario?

questions.text: Do nothing as it is not your responsibility to take care of the other students’ sections
questions.explanation: This is very inappropriate as, in a group environment, members should seek to collaborate and check in on each other – rather than solely focusing on their own work

questions.text: Organise a meeting to check in with the progress of the other group members
questions.explanation: A meeting would be a great chance to communicate with the other group members and see how they’re going on their sections

questions.text: Once you have finished your section, ask the group members if they require any additional assistance
questions.explanation: While it is appropriate to offer this assistance, doing so after you have finished your section may be too late – instead, you should ask the group members about their progress beforehand

questions.text: Complain to the academic tutor
questions.explanation: While it is not extremely inappropriate to notify the tutor, you should first seek to consult the group members and resolve the situation at a local level before escalating it

questions.text: Organise a work schedule for the other group members to adhere to in order to finish their sections by the due date
questions.explanation: While this may help the group finish in time, you should not force them to follow a schedule that you have created – rather open, two-way communication is paramount
